At the time this review is being written, the game is now around 8 and a half years old, and still looks STUNNING! The storyline, in my opinion, is fantastic, and there are plenty of fan theories about it that can be found by a simple Google search. The price des this game justice. The testchambers are put together in progressive difficulty, and the escape is one of my best moments on gaming, although I do play mostly simulators, so there may be better ones.
You need logic in this game, think outside the box, but not too far outside the box. I'd also take the things GLaDOS says with a pinch of salt, maily because she is very sarcastic. Need more persuasion, read the other 24, 516 positive reviews. Just BUY IT! NOW! IT'S MANDATORY!

Portal fue un experimento que hizo Valve de un nuevo estilo de juego que marcaría también un antes y un después en la propia compañia. El juego nos sitúa en una chica que de repente despierta en una sala experimental, sola y con una serie de pruebas que tendrá que superar con una pistola de portales. El ambiente es muy similar a la película Cube, la única diferencia es que en el juego los cubos los tendremos que usar en casi todas las pruebas para abrir interruptores y activar plataformas de movimiento de Aperture Science. 
Pero lo mejor del juego se lo lleva sin duda GlaDOS, una voz robótica que nos "guía" en todo el juego haciendo que primero parezca una amiga y que más adelante te des cuenta que se está riendo de ti con sus sarcasmos (véase por ejemplo "si se marea por la sed, tiene permiso para desmayarse"). Un papel bastante importante que incluso su relevancia se incrementará en su secuela Portal 2.
what is there to say? do you even know the internet if you need to come to the reviews? just go buy it already

It's short, but great.  It's worth playing for the cultural relevance alone.  The gameplay's good.  The writing's good.  The ending's good.  It's short.  There's no reason not to play it.

A classic game and a must for those in the PC gaming community. The story in entertaining but short -- it took me around 4 hours to complete. Pick this up on sale, as the Portal bundle frequently drops down to $5. 

Also, it probably runs on even the most underpowered hardware, given that it is a well-optimized nine-year-old game.

Portal est un jeu qui permet de rentrer dans l'univers des jeux Portal même si sa durée de vie est plutôt limitée. Je pense qu'il reste indispensable de jouer à cet opus avant d'attaquer Portal 2. 
Les graphismes du jeu sont corrects et permettent une bonne immersion dans l'ambiance. L'histoire, peu présente, reste quand même principale dans l'objectif de l'héroine : s'échapper. La caractéristique la plus importante du jeu reste évidemment la qualité du joueur à se débrouiller pour avancer en résolvant des énigmes de façon 3D. Bien que la difficulté soit moindre que dans son sucesseur, Portal reste une icône dans les jeux vidéos.
Je vous conseille donc de l'acheter dès que vous en aurez la possiblité ;)

"Best game ever" is a term that's been thrown around a lot in the community, but what defines a game that is considered the best game ever? While this is entirely subjective, in my opinion the best game ever is a game that has no flaws what so ever. And it is not a subjective opinion when I say that Portal has no flaws what so ever. So if you go by my standards for deciding what the best game ever is, then Portal certainly meets the requirements. 

Before I get into the review I'm going to disqualify a few of the common criticisms I've heard about the game and explain why they are invalid. If you aren't interested in me ranting because you already know that I'm right then skip to the actual review part.

#1 - "It's too short" ... Ok it's only 3-4 hours long but that's so it doesn't over stay it's welcome and narrows the gap between you and the fantastic ending. Besides, what kind of criticism is that? You can criticize a game for being too drawn out, which can make even the most enjoyable experience down right boring. But declaring a 3-4 hour game as too short is not a reasonable criticism when you only payed 10 bucks for it (most of the time you can buy it for much less than that during Steam sales) And if you're still hungry for more of the raw gameplay after the campaign, there are alternate versions of some of the levels and 3 types of challenge modes for each of the levels which brings the total game completion time to around 8 hours. I'd say that's about right for a $10 game. I mean, I've played games with the same amount of content that are double the price.

#2 - "It has no replay value" ... Ok going to stop you there, name one puzzle game that has any replay value (and isn't randomly generated like Tetris). Of course you can't because once you solve the puzzles you know the answers and therefore won't have the satisfaction of solving it again because you already know how. Stop me if that sounds like a simple observation, but apparently it didn't cross the mind of the moron who came up with that criticism.



The Actual Review Part:

Portal is a unique, first person, physics puzzle game in which you are equipped with a gun that you can shoot portals from. You can only shoot two portals at a time and as you probably guessed when you go through one portal you come out the other. The only puzzle you are tasked with is navigating increasingly elaborate obstacle courses by shooting and jumping through portals. Did I mention the courses occasionally have death traps as well?

When asked about what Portal does right it's tempting to just say "everything" and be done with it. But I think the reason it's flawless is because it took a unique and original game concept then ironed it out to perfection. The entire game is focused on perfecting it's central mechanics, the portals and portal gun.

The strongest evidence for this is the fact that the entire narrative is just a framing device to hide the fact that the game is 90% tutorial. The developers knew that the very concept of portals would blow people's mind so they made the level design tight. Almost every detail in each level's design is there to reinforce and help you understand the mechanics.

Everything from the first time a portal opens to the last test chamber is there to further your understanding of how portals work. What's amazing is how the game effectively teaches you these mechanics by only using it's stellar level design and it's genius environmental design. Which speaking of environmental design, the look and feel of the environments fit the narrative perfectly so nothing ever feels out of place. What's cool is how the game's brilliant and subtle use of lighting and audio cues are so naturally placed within the environment it helps subconsciously guide you through the game without ever breaking immersion or switching the tone of the game. And by the way the tone of Portal is perfect and not a single detail in it's narrative or environmental design seems out of place. On top of that, it's excellent yet subtle environmental storytelling gives the narrative a bit of depth and the absolutely hilarious comments from the game's antagonist, Glados the evil AI is just the icing on the cake.
An amazing game!
Portal is an amazing game. You can beat it in a couple of hours, but you will enjoy every minute of it. If you enjoy Portal, don't forget to play Portal 2!

Portal is an FPS with no ammo. No bullet proof vests. No tanks. No aliens. Not a drop of blood. Yet it is probably the best FPS I've ever played. It's short, sweet, and will actually make you use your brain. You'll love every minute and you won't look at gaming the same every again.

I REALLY like Portal.  It's one of my favorite series of all-time.  Yes, the mechanics feel a little dated by modern standards and the controls aren't as responsive as I wish they would be.  Even still, there's not much that can be said about Portal other than to just try the mind-bending puzzles for yourself.

Portal is an amazing game. Coming from another project called Narbacular Drop, Portal is a Valve must-see. In Portal, you play as Cell, a test subject for Aperture Science. You are given a state-of-the-art Portal Gun to navigate puzzles in your way. Even though most of this game can be considered a tutorial, most people just forget that because of the enjoyment this game can pack. I reccomend Portal to you if you need a short but sweet experience.

[h1] Тут портал и там портал, прыгнул вниз и ввысь упал... [/h1]

Оранжевая коробка в свое время (твою мать, почти 10 лет назад???) подарила многим игрокам среди прочего: командного ТФ2 и продолжения истории главного гладиатора на монтировках в ХЛ2Э2 еще и совершенно новую историю с [strike] блэкджеком и путанами [/strike] удивительной и понравившейся миллионам людей игровой механикой - еще легендарный теперь уже Portal (обожаю лаконичность). Нам подарили портальную пушку, Челл (явно поклонница Гордона "Наше все" Фримена - молчит всю игру), ГЛэДОС (русская озвучка во второй части мне нравится в разы больше), мемы, цитаты, нашего нового друга - куба-компаньона, головоломистые головоломки, возможность бесконечно падать меж порталами, вообще никуда не продвигаясь по сюжету, а также - сюжет в духе некоторых знаменитых историй таких как "Куб" к примеру (не знаю почему) или "Космическая одиссея 2001".

Вы же знаете, что тортик - это ложь? Фансервиса в такой короткой игре получилось немало - каждый второй игрок фактически заболел этой игрой, всё в Интернете пестрило кубом-с-сердечком, порталами и прочими атрибутами. А уж сарказм ГЛэДОС чего стоил... плюс песня в титрах Still Alive. К счастью, все прошло и к моменту выхода второй части уже поуспокоились  в достаточной мере, чтобы не пестрить кубами, турельками и порталами везде, где можно (но черт возьми "Я не такая..." - это шедевр!).

Знаете прикол про "мы встроили тебе Челл в Челл, чтобы ты, будучи Челл, мог смотреть на Челл в Челл, пока смотришь на Челл"? А, нет, это ко второй части, к рисункам на стенах. Не суть.

Как говорится, каждый уважающий себя игрок...

[i]I’m not sure who I am, where I am and what is generally going on. I woke up in this weird room...[/i]
 
[b]Update #1[/b]
Setting the constant state of confusion aside for a moment, I have to admit I do rock this ‘jumpsuit look’! 
[b]Update #2[/b]
Freaking [b]laser-guns[/b]?!
[b]Update #3[/b]
Just spent half a day trying to find an alternative way out, that is without having to undergo drowning in pools of toxic waste or being laser-shot into oblivion. No progress as of yet but I’m keeping positive.
[b]Update #4[/b]
Man, this place is falling apart. Managed to fit a cube between the wall tile and the wall itself while the hydraulics arm(!) was extended. Take that, stupid machine voice!
[b]Update #5[/b]
There’s a maintenance door here! It’s locked, just my luck, but I’ll figure it out! Oh, and someone scribbled something about a cake on one of the inside walls. I was way too busy to read the whole thing. Meh, probably not important.
[b]Update #6[/b]
Throwing buckets and a radio at the maintenance door does not seem to work. Looking for a better way to open it.
[b]Update #7[/b]
I sat down in a corner and cried for almost an hour yesterday. Or was it today? I’m not sure. 
[b]Update #8[/b]
Found a juice box. Was empty. Did not fit into the keyhole.
[b]Update #9[/b]
I think I’m being watched.
[b]Update #10[/b]
I touched myself.
I do not fit into the keyhole either.


[i]In conclusion,
Would not play again.
But just because anti-psychotic drugs are hella expensive.[/i]
